item.title: Can steam really light a match?
item.description: A science experiment tests whether steam can generate enough energy to ignite a match, breaking down the physics and heat transfer behind the result.

media:content.media:title: Can steam really light a match?
media:content.media:description: A science experiment tests whether steam can generate enough energy to ignite a match, breaking down the physics and heat transfer behind the result.

item.title: Why do balls untwist?
item.description: A simple physics experiment with a basketball explains why twisted objects naturally untwist, revealing how tension, torque, and stored energy work together.

item.title: Can power lines really light a bulb in your hand?
item.description: A science experiment tests whether electrical induction from power lines is strong enough to light a bulb, explaining the physics behind whatâ€™s actually happening.

item.title: What happens when welded sand is crushed?
item.description: A physics experiment uses a hydraulic press to crush welded sand, revealing how extreme pressure changes its structure and behavior.

item.title: What happens if you feed a Venus flytrap blood?
item.description: A controlled science experiment examines how a Venus flytrap reacts when exposed to human blood, explaining what the plant can and cannot process from a biological standpoint.

item.title: Bendable rocks are weird!
item.description: A surprising experiment shows how certain rocks can bend instead of breaking, revealing unexpected physical properties and the science behind them.
